titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Second day of imprisonment by contrary winds. Made out my account for the Secretary of State, and wrote him a letter enclosing it.— Spent the remainder of the day in walking, in reading, in the usual expedients to drive away tedious time.

2. Third day of detention by the wind.— Employed the principal part of it in writing to my father. Mr: Dandridge came from the Hague to see us: dined with us, and returned in the Evening. Reading Tom Jones.

3. Fourth day of detention by the wind. Have already got into something like a regular course of life. I have books, and conveniences for writing. A billiard table in the House, gives the means of amusement and exercise. I played with my brother, this afternoon; the first time, I think that I have attempted such a thing these twelve years.— Was caught in the rain walking— There is now a fair, at this place.— Received this Evening from the Hague, the Droit Public de l’Europe, for Mr: King; for which I sent yesterday by Mr: Dandridge.— Latter part of this day very stormy.

4. Anniversary of Independence. Passed the former part of the day, in writing Letters. Walked from two to three. Game of Billiards after dinner. Reading, the Politique de tous les Cabinets. Very noisy day in the house where we lodge, and a sort of Ball, at night.

5. Wrote a Letter to Mr: Wadström this morning and enclosed it to Reuterswerd. Mr: Murray and Mr: Dandridge came to see us; but being obliged to return the same Evening, staid not more than half an hour. Brought me the Paris newspapers to the 1st: instt: and a couple of pamphlets.

6. Seventh day of detention by the wind. Mr: Aguiar arrived here this morning with the intention to go over with us to England. Mr: Brito came with him, but returned to the Hague. Wrote a long Letter to my mother.— Received one this afternoon from Mr: Murray containing news from America to the 23d: of May; and a Philadelphia Paper of that date. Must wait to hear further.

7. Eighth day of detention by the wind. Spent it like all the rest.— Mr: Horrÿ came to see us, and dined with us. Brought me Letters from Genl: Pinckney and Mr: Murray, with some very unpleasant intelligence, personally concerning myself.

8. Ninth day of detention by the wind. But it has at length become fair, and if it so continues promises departure to-morrow. Weather fine. Visit this afternoon from Mr: Havart and Mr: Fettiplace. Prepared to sail in the morning. Noisy night, the closing of the Fair and the Ball at the House where we lodged was very much crowded.

9. Up this morning at about 4. Sailed an hour or two after in a Dutch Bomb under Prussian colours. The Alexander Captain de Vries. Several others sailed at the same time. Wind fair, but very light almost through the whole day. One of our companions at sailing gained much upon us. Met upon the wharf a french man by the name of Catelen, who entered into conversation with me, and in five minutes told me anecdotes of Mr: Short, Mrs: Fenwick, Madm de Staal, Mr: Dubuc, and various other persons and things. A perfect specimen of the french character. We atchieved nearly half the passage this day. Weather very fine.

10. The day almost entirely calm and extremely warm. Our accommodations are indifferent, and we have twelve passengers on board a very small vessel. But we have a good Captain. Towards night the wind freshened up a little.

11. Made Land early this morning, but as the wind was small, we passed the whole day in going up the river as far as Gravesend. Came to Anchor about seven miles below it at 6 in the Afternoon, and about an hour afterwards the vessel that left Maassluys in Company with us came up; very much to the satisfaction of our Mate, and some of our Passengers. We reached Gravesend, between 12 and 1 in the morning, but determined not to go on shore until the morning.

12. By the regulations prescribed here in consequence of the War, no Passenger is allowed to go up beyond Gravesend in the vessel himself, or to take out any of his baggage, all of which must go to London. We landed in the morning, and were employed most of the forenoon in obtaining the expedition of our Passports.— They are all examined here by a Mr: Mazzinghi, and sent to the Duke of Portland’s (Secretary of State) office, whence they must be returned with permission for the holder to go up to London. In the mean time the passengers are detained, with a guard placed over them. Mr: Mazzinghi however dispensed with this circumstance in our behalf, in consideration of my public character, and in that of Mr: Aguiar, as he was charged with dispatches from the Portuguese Minister in Holland, to his Government. We all left Gravesend therefore with a Coach & four, between 12 & 1 o’clock, and arrived in London at Osborne’s Hotel, in the Adelphi at about 5. in the afternoon.— I could not go out this Evening, and retired at an early hour.

13. Went down this morning to Mr Johnson’s, after a visit from Mr: Hall & Mr: Rogers. Found my friends there, and particularly my best friend, well.— Went from thence and called on Mr: King, whom I found going to the Drawing Room.— Called likewise on Mr: Gore, Mr: Trumbull and Mr: Pinkney, the American Commissioners. The last I had not seen before. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s, with Mr: Trumbull and Captn: Crosier.
14. Messrs: Rogers, F. Hall, and J. Hall breakfasted with us. Received afterwards visits from Mr: King, and Mr: Gore.— Dined again and passed the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.

15. Visit this forenoon from Mr: Pinkney and Mr: Lenox; from Mr: Spooner & Mr: Cabot. Paid several also myself: find it as difficult to do any business here as usual. Dined with Mr: King.— Evening, home early. Got my baggage at last.

16. Visit this morning from Coll: Trumbull. At home all the morning writing as much as I could. My brother went to the Park. We both dined at Mr: Johnson’s, and passed the Evening there. Violent thunder shower in the night.

17. Weather which has been extremely warm, somewhat cooled by the shower. Finished this day a Letter to the Secretary of State.— Paid some more visits. At Mr: Bird’s, Mr: Vaughan’s, Sir F. Baring’s &c.— At Lackington’s: but purchased not much.— Dined at Mr: Johnson’s.— In the afternoon we went on board the Mary, Captain Crozier, a vessel belonging to Mr: Johnson, and which he has offered to carry us to Lisbon.— We had a pleasant time, and the vessel is a very good one; but I am turned away from the Lisbon course.— Mr: Brooks was with us.

18. As I was going out this morning, I met Mr: King, who delivered me Letters from the Secretary of State of 27. May and 1 June, and from my father of 2 June. They direct me, not to proceed to Lisbon, but wait here for a Commission and Instructions to the Court of Berlin.— Paid a number of visits, and spent an hour with Mr: King. Dined and passed the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.

19. Dined at Mr: Gore’s. Mr: & Mrs: Pinkney, Coll: Trumbull, and the two Messrs: Hall, were there. Had quite an American dinner.— Mrs: Pinkney, is a pretty and a pleasant woman. Mr: Gore remembered it as the Commencement day at Harvard College.— In the Evening, Mr: Bird, and Mr: W. Vaughan were there.

20. Called again on Mr: King, and had a long conversation with him upon our public affairs, concerning a convoy for American vessels, and also the raising money to conclude our business with the Barbary powers. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s— Evening at home.

div.p: 21. Called at Mr: Johnson’s sometime before dinner, and received his directions concerning his affairs with his former partners, in case I should ever have occasion for them.— Made our arrangements for my marriage which is to take place on Wednesday next.— Two Messrs: Hall and my brother came in the Evening.

22. Received this forenoon two letters from my mother of the 15th: and 24th: of June. Writing a little myself; but not much. besides the usual difficulties of writing in London, the present occasion takes much of my time, and denies me the power of application for the remainder. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Home early in the Evening.

23. Visit this morning from Mr: Claggett, & from Mr: Hall.— Went to dine with Sir F. Baring at Lee, near Lewesham, six miles out of town. Found a family of invalids.— His situation very fine. His two daughters & Sons in Law were there— Labouchere has married the youngest since I was in England last.— We returned to town early in the Evening; the Country round London is remarkably beautiful—

div.p: 24. Called this morning before 11 o’clock upon Mr: Johnson and went with him to get a licence at Doctor’s Commons.— With the assistance of the Proctor Mr Bogg,—I took the Oath required, gave the usual bond and obtained the licence. Paid several visits; to Mr: Calhoun, Mr: Cabot, and lastly to Mr: King, with whom I had a long & interesting conversation, concerning Mr: Gerry,—Talleyrand & the change of french Ministers, Genl: Pinckney &c. As I was coming away found J. Hall who came home with me. We called on Rogers. Dined with Foster at N. 9. Bloomsbury Square, at a Mr: Gray’s—a son of Harrison Gray the old Massachusetts Treasurer.— F. Hall and my brother went to the Theatre in the Evening. J. Hall and myself went to Mr: Johnson’s. Found Mr: & Mrs: Pinkney there; & Mr: Brooks.— They did not remain long. Hall & myself stayed to supper.

div.p: 25. Visit from Mr: F. Cabot in the forenoon. Spent the principal part of the day in preparing for the ceremony of to-morrow. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s— As I was going out, met Mr: King, who was coming to see me.— Mr: Calhoun with us.— He went in the Evening, with my brother to Vauxhall. Dr: Bancroft dined at Mr: Johnson’s.

div.p: 26. At nine this morning I went accompanied by my brother to Mr: Johnson’s, and thence to the Church of the Parish of All Hallows, Barking, where I was married to Louisa Catherine Johnson, the second Daughter of Joshua and Catherine Johnson,—by Mr: Hewlett— Mr: Johnson’s family, Mr: Brooks, my brother and Mr: J. Hall were present. We were married before 11. in the morning: And immediately after, went out to see Tilney House; one of the splendid Country seats for which this Country is distinguished.— We returned at about 4. P.M. The company before mentioned, and Mrs: Court a friend of Mrs: Johnson, dined with us.— The day was a very long one and closed at about 11.

27. Walked up, after breakfast to the Adelphi, and returned with my brother. At about 1 afternoon we went, the whole family together with Mr: Hall, in a party to Shuter’s Hill where we dined. The weather continues extremely warm— We returned early in the Evening.

28. Walk up to the Adelphi, after breakfast. Visit to Mr: Erving: to Mr: King, with whom I had much political conversation. Returned with him to the Adelphi.— Dined at Mr: Claggett’s.— Hall went with us. Met Mr: Marriott there, and Mr: Pratt.— Hall, and my brother and Mr: Brooks returned with us to Mr: Johnson’s, where we had a pleasant party at supper.

div.p: 29. All the former part of the day at the Adelphi, writing. Large company to dine at Mr: Johnson’s. Mr: and Mrs: Pinkney. Mrs: Hewlett, two Miss Bancrofts. J. Hall &c. were of the company. It is among the appendages to the ceremony, from which I should have been willingly relieved.

30. Went to Church this morning, at the foundling Hospital. Mr: Hewlett preached the Sermon, which was very good. The singing also good.— Paid a visit after Church to Mr: & Mrs: Pinkney. Ride round the Park. Stopped at the Adelphi upon our return. Dinner and Evening with the family only: my brother went this day with Mr: Calhoun to Windsor.
31. Going up to the Adelphi, with met J. Hall. He sat with me all the forenoon. Dined with us at Mr: Johnson’s. My brother returned this morning from Windsor.
